summary: This is an email chain from November 18, 2021, involving a U.S. Attorney's Office (USANYS) and a Telegraph journalist, Josie Ensor. The journalist inquires about reporting an unredacted witness name that was inadvertently left public in a court filing (Document #453) in the United States vs. Ghislaine Maxwell case. The prosecutor urgently requests the journalist not to publish the name while they verify the information.

persons.name: Josie Ensor
persons.context: A correspondent for the British Telegraph newspaper who emails the U.S. Attorney's Office to ask if they can report on an unredacted witness name found in a public court filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the legal case 'United States vs. Maxwell'. The email discusses a filing in her trial where a witness name was left unredacted.

connections.description: Ensor is a journalist inquiring about and reporting on the legal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Journalist Inquiry About Unredacted Witness Name
events.description: Journalist Josie Ensor contacts the U.S. Attorney's Office to ask if she can report on a witness name that was left unredacted in a public court filing (Document #453) in the United States vs. Ghislaine Maxwell case.

keyFacts: A journalist from The Telegraph identified an unredacted witness name in a public court filing (Document #453) in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.
The U.S. Attorney's Office was urgently notified and asked the journalist not to publish the name while they verified the information.
The document reveals a potential breach of witness anonymity protections ordered by the judge in the Maxwell case.
The correspondence highlights media scrutiny and procedural concerns regarding the handling of sensitive witness information in high-profile cases.
